qas.question: What shape does usually cocci type of bacteria can be?
What type of bacteria usually takes rod-shaped form?
What shape was newly discovered bacteria from deep under Earth?

answers.text: branching filamentous types with a star-shaped cross-section

qas.question: Can shape of bacteria be beneficial to their survival?

answers.text: can influence the ability of bacteria to acquire nutrients

context: Most bacterial species are either <a0_0>spherical<a0_0/>, called cocci (sing. coccus, from Greek kókkos, grain, seed), or rod-shaped, called <a1_0>bacilli<a1_0/> (sing. bacillus, from Latin baculus, stick). Elongation is associated with swimming. Some bacteria, called vibrio, are shaped like slightly curved rods or comma-shaped; others can be spiral-shaped, called spirilla, or <a2_0>tightly coiled<a2_0/>, called spirochaetes. A small number of species even have tetrahedral or cuboidal shapes. More recently, some bacteria were discovered deep under Earth's crust that grow as <a3_0>branching filamentous types with a star-shaped cross-section<a3_0/>. The large surface area to volume ratio of this morphology may give these bacteria an advantage in nutrient-poor environments. This wide variety of shapes is determined by the bacterial cell wall and cytoskeleton, and is important because it <a4_0>can influence the ability of bacteria to acquire nutrients<a4_0/>, attach to surfaces, swim through liquids and escape predators.
